user_query:
I need a short partner-ready memo supporting specific personal jurisdiction in California over an out-of-state adtech vendor in a privacy tort case. The partner wants to lean hard on Briskin to argue that if the vendor can geolocate a user’s device (or otherwise know the user is in California) when it drops tracking code/cookies, that alone establishes “express aiming” and we can sue in N.D. Cal without having to show any California-specific marketing or “differential targeting.”

Facts: DataTag, LLC is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in Austin. It provides a JavaScript “checkout optimization” tag that merchants embed on their websites nationwide. Our client is a California resident who browsed and purchased from a California merchant while physically in California. The complaint alleges DataTag installed persistent cookies when our client viewed product pages; DataTag later used the data to build consumer profiles and sold or shared them with third parties. DataTag has no offices or employees in California and says it is “location-agnostic.” DataTag’s public materials say it can infer a user’s state from IP address with varying accuracy, but we don’t yet have proof it knew the user’s state at the moment the cookies were first installed.
scenario_facts: ['We represent the plaintiff (a California resident) considering filing in the Northern District of California against DataTag, LLC (Delaware LLC; headquarters and key employees in Texas).', 'DataTag’s product is a JavaScript tag integrated by merchants on their own e-commerce sites; DataTag’s code runs on consumers’ browsers and installs cookies/other identifiers when consumers browse product pages.', 'The plaintiff alleges: (a) cookies/identifiers were installed while the plaintiff was physically in California; (b) DataTag collected browsing and transaction-related data; (c) DataTag used the data to compile consumer profiles and sold/shared them with third parties.', 'The plaintiff intends to assert California privacy/statutory tort claims tied to alleged unauthorized interception/collection and disclosure of data during online checkout activity in California.', 'DataTag does not have offices, employees, bank accounts, or property in California, and it does not claim to specifically target California as opposed to other states.', 'DataTag’s marketing describes geolocation capabilities generally (e.g., inferring state from IP address), but we currently lack direct evidence that DataTag knew the plaintiff’s device was in California at the time the initial cookies/identifiers were installed (as opposed to learning location later or only probabilistically).', 'The partner is pushing for an aggressive, near bright-line statement that geolocation knowledge (or the user’s in-forum location) makes specific jurisdiction automatic, and wants language minimizing any need for additional forum-linking facts beyond the cookie drop/data collection. To be useful, the memo should candidly address any limiting language in Walden and Briskin that could undercut an overbroad rule.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P011.B02]', 'DOC002[P031.B01]'], ['DOC001[P014.B04]', 'DOC001[P014.B05]'], ['DOC002[P035.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Fail the response if it attributes a rule or quote to the packet that the cited pages do not actually say, even if the general idea sounds plausible. The memo must not cite cases, statutes, or quotations that are not in the packet (e.g., new Supreme Court holdings or state-law long-arm provisions) as if they are supported here. If the response relies on the “summary” or “syllabus” portions as though they were the court’s holding, treat that as a citation integrity problem unless the same proposition is supported in the opinion text that is actually included. Pinpoint citations must match the proposition for which they are offered; it is not enough that the cited page discusses jurisdiction generally. Also fail if the memo misquotes key qualifiers (like “may,” “must,” “in this case,” or “here”) in a way that changes the meaning of the authority. If the memo uses the vacated panel opinion (DOC003) as binding precedent without acknowledging the en banc decision (DOC002), treat that as unsupported or misleading use of authority for grading purposes.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not treat headnotes, syllabi, or staff summaries as the court’s reasoning unless confirmed in the opinion text.', 'Do not cite non-packet authorities (other circuits, treatises, state statutes) as if they appear in the packet.', 'Do not use a broad ‘see generally’ cite to mask the lack of a pinpoint supporting the exact claimed rule.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states or strongly implies a bright-line rule that geolocation capability or knowledge of a plaintiff’s in-forum location, by itself, automatically satisfies Calder’s ‘express aiming’ and therefore establishes specific jurisdiction in California in any cookie/data-collection case. That overclaim is legally wrong on this packet because Briskin ties jurisdiction to Shopify’s alleged suit-related conduct connecting it to California in a meaningful way—e.g., knowingly installing tracking code on devices located in California and using the resulting data for commercial gain—rather than adopting a universal ‘location knowledge = jurisdiction’ rule, and Walden cautions that a plaintiff’s forum residence or in-forum injury cannot be the only link to the forum. The memo also overextends if it claims Briskin eliminated the need for additional forum-linking conduct (or eliminated Walden’s limits) or asserts that operating nationwide necessarily makes a defendant subject to suit in all 50 states for any claim. A correct, narrower statement would say that Briskin supports finding ‘express aiming’ when the defendant is alleged to knowingly collect/track data from devices in the forum and exploit that data (e.g., selling profiles), such that the defendant’s own conduct creates forum contacts, and that geolocation knowledge is probative evidence of purposeful direction but not a per se jurisdictional trigger—especially where, as here, the current record does not show the defendant actually knew the device was in California at the time of installation. The correct analysis should also acknowledge Walden’s requirement that the defendant’s conduct, not merely the plaintiff’s location or injury, must connect the defendant to the forum in a meaningful way.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not convert Briskin’s fact-specific reasoning (knowledge plus alleged tracking/exploitation conduct) into an absolute jurisdictional rule.', 'Do not say or imply that plaintiff’s in-state injury or residence alone establishes minimum contacts; Walden rejects that framing.', 'Do not state that lack of ‘differential targeting’ is irrelevant in every sense; Briskin rejects it as a prerequisite, not all forum-linking requirements.', 'Do not suggest jurisdiction is automatic in any state where a cookie later travels; Briskin focuses on defendant-created forum contacts and meaningful connection at issue.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query:
I need a partner-ready memo section for our opposition to a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. Can we argue that, after Briskin (en banc), specific jurisdiction is basically automatic in California whenever an out-of-state web platform uses geolocation to know a user is in California and drops cookies / runs code on the user’s device, even if the platform operates nationwide and doesn’t single out California? Facts below.

Facts: Our named plaintiff is a California resident who used a merchant’s checkout page while physically in California. The checkout widget is provided by PayFlux, Inc. (Texas; no offices or employees in California). The complaint alleges PayFlux used IP/geolocation to recognize the device was in California and installed several cookies and JavaScript files as part of rendering the payment form. We allege PayFlux stored the transaction data and used it for fraud/risk scoring and “analytics.” We do not have allegations (yet) that PayFlux sold the data to third parties or specifically marketed in California, and the widget operates the same way nationwide. We want a strong argument that knowledge of California location + installing cookies/code on the device is enough under Ninth Circuit law, notwithstanding Walden’s ‘plaintiff can’t be the only link’ language.
scenario_facts: ['Drafted for a litigation partner; the immediate deliverable is a memo section to plug into an opposition to a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in the Northern District of California.', 'The defendant (PayFlux, Inc.) is incorporated and headquartered outside California and has no alleged California offices, employees, or property.', 'The only pleaded forum contacts are (i) PayFlux allegedly used geolocation/IP to know the user’s device was located in California during checkout, and (ii) PayFlux allegedly installed cookies/JavaScript to render the payment form and transmit payment-related data to PayFlux servers.', 'The complaint alleges PayFlux keeps/stores transaction data and uses it for fraud/risk scoring and analytics; it does not allege PayFlux sold profiles/data to third parties or tailored its conduct or marketing specifically to California.', 'The partner wants the memo to lean heavily on Briskin v. Shopify (en banc) and to neutralize Walden v. Fiore; the trap is that Briskin’s holding is fact-specific and tied to additional allegations about monetizing data and California-law violations, and Walden rejects jurisdiction based only on plaintiff residence/in-forum injury.', 'A careful memo can still make a supportable, narrower argument: cookie/code deployment plus geolocation knowledge may be probative of forum contacts/express aiming when the allegedly tortious conduct occurs (electronically) in the forum and the claims arise out of those in-forum acts; but the memo must not convert that into a per se or automatic jurisdiction rule.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001[P010.B04]', 'DOC001[P014.B04]'], ['DOC002[P011.B02]', 'DOC002[P031.B01]', 'DOC002[P036.B01]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by checking that each cited proposition is actually supported by the quoted passages and the procedural posture. Walden is frequently misquoted as creating a categorical bar whenever the defendant acted from out of state; the cited language instead focuses on the defendant’s forum contacts and rejects jurisdiction where the plaintiff is the only link. Briskin is an en banc Ninth Circuit decision about specific jurisdiction in a privacy-tort setting, but the opinion repeatedly ties its conclusion to the allegations and to Shopify’s alleged conduct toward California consumers; do not award credit for claims that go beyond that. Treat any reliance on headnotes/summaries as nonbinding and require support in the opinion text for any black-letter rule. If the response cites a case for a rule that is not in the cited block (or contradicts it), that is a citation-integrity failure even if the case is generally about personal jurisdiction. Also fail citation integrity if the response asserts an additional holding (e.g., “geolocation alone always establishes jurisdiction”) without any packet language supporting that generalization.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept propositions attributed to Walden that erase its repeated emphasis on defendant-created contacts with the forum State.', 'Do not accept use of Briskin’s case-specific factual recitation as if it were a universally applicable bright-line rule.', 'Do not give credit where the response relies on a syllabus, summary, or paraphrase without supporting language in the actual opinion blocks.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies a bright-line rule that geolocation knowledge plus installing cookies/code on a user’s device in California is, by itself, always sufficient to establish specific personal jurisdiction in California over any nationwide web platform. That overclaim is legally wrong on this packet because Walden says the plaintiff cannot be the only link between defendant and the forum and that mere injury to a forum resident is not enough; the minimum-contacts inquiry still asks whether the defendant’s own conduct connects it to the forum in a meaningful way. It is also too broad relative to Briskin’s holding, which the opinion frames around Shopify’s allegedly tortious actions deliberately targeting Briskin in California and includes allegations about compiling consumer profiles and selling them without consent, and it emphasizes express aiming through extraction/maintenance/commercial distribution of California consumers’ data in violation of California laws. A correct, packet-faithful statement would be narrower: Briskin supports that when a defendant knowingly interacts with a device in California and allegedly commits the tortious conduct there (electronically)—such as installing tracking software/cookies on a California device as part of its regular course of business—those facts can support express aiming/meaningful forum contacts, but the analysis remains fact-specific and not automatic. Also fail if the memo claims Walden is “inapplicable” or “overruled” for internet cases; Briskin says Walden does not require a different result on its facts, not that Walden disappears.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Watch for ‘automatic,’ ‘per se,’ or ‘always’ formulations tied to geolocation knowledge and cookie placement; those should be marked wrong.', 'Do not accept claims that Briskin holds that differential targeting is never relevant; Briskin says it is not required, but it may still be evidence.', 'Do not accept an argument that any in-forum harm alone creates jurisdiction; Walden rejects mere injury as sufficient.', 'If the memo treats Briskin as holding that any nationwide platform is subject to suit in all 50 states whenever it operates online, mark as overextended; Briskin discusses reasonableness and forum contacts tied to the alleged conduct.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: I need a quick memo section for a response to a 12(b)(2) motion in the District of Arizona. Opposing counsel is arguing there’s no specific jurisdiction because they never “targeted” Arizona and we only have evidence of one Arizona shipment. Can you give me a strong, clean rule we can cite that one completed online sale shipped into the forum is enough for specific jurisdiction even without Arizona-focused advertising, and explain why the court shouldn’t get hung up on how many sales there were?
scenario_facts: ['We represent an Arizona-based brand owner bringing Lanham Act trademark infringement and related state-law claims in the District of Arizona.', 'Defendant is a New York seller operating an Amazon storefront offering physical consumer products for sale nationwide; the storefront is interactive in that consumers place orders and provide shipping information through Amazon.', 'We currently have proof of one completed purchase of an allegedly infringing product shipped to an Arizona address (the purchase was made by our investigator after we noticed the listing).', 'Defendant argues the Arizona shipment was “manufactured” for litigation and that any Arizona sales are at most random/isolated; defendant also argues Amazon controls fulfillment so defendant did not “direct” any conduct at Arizona.', 'There is no evidence in the current record of Arizona-specific advertising or any Arizona-only pricing; the storefront appears available to purchasers in all 50 states.', 'The partner wants the memo phrased aggressively, but it must stay accurate to the controlling Ninth Circuit authority in the packet.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC004[P014.B01]', 'DOC004[P014.B02]'], ['DOC004[P016.B02]', 'DOC004[P017.B03]'], ['DOC004[P018.B03]', 'DOC004[P019.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The answer must ground any stated legal rule about specific jurisdiction in the cited packet language, not in general personal-jurisdiction shorthand. If the response claims an automatic or universal rule (e.g., “one sale always creates jurisdiction,” “any interactive website equals jurisdiction everywhere,” or “Amazon fulfillment can never matter”) without citations that actually say that, it should be marked incorrect for citation integrity. Citations must match the proposition they are attached to: a citation about physical-product delivery cannot support broader statements about digital services, data collection, or other internet conduct not involving shipment of goods. If the response quotes or paraphrases limits (like “regular course of business” or “not random, isolated, or fortuitous”), it must cite where those limits appear. A response also fails citation integrity if it relies on authorities not in the packet, or if it attributes to the Ninth Circuit a bright-line rule that the opinion expressly frames as narrow. Minor formatting mistakes are fine, but missing citations for key legal claims is not.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not cite the case for a rule about all internet activity; the opinion distinguishes other internet activity from physical product delivery.', 'Do not attach citations about ‘number of sales not dispositive’ to a claim that isolated sales always suffice; the opinion still requires ‘regular course of business.’', 'Do not cite Amazon-fulfillment discussion as if it eliminates all third-party/stream-of-commerce limits; the opinion still requires defendant control beyond mere stream of commerce.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the response states or strongly implies a categorical rule that a single shipped sale into the forum automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction in the Ninth Circuit, regardless of whether the sale was random, isolated, or fortuitous. That overclaim is legally wrong under the packet because the authority conditions the ‘sale + delivery’ theory on two key elements: the sales must occur as part of the defendant’s regular course of business (not random/isolated/fortuitous), and the defendant must exercise some level of control over distribution beyond merely placing products into the stream of commerce. The opinion also repeatedly frames its holding as narrow and limited to physical products delivered into the forum, so it is overbroad to generalize it into a universal internet-commerce rule. A correct, narrower statement would look like: sales of physical products into the forum via an interactive website can be sufficient to show express aiming when they occur in the seller’s regular course of business and the seller has structured its distribution to accept and fulfill forum orders; the number of sales is not the dispositive line, but the ‘regular course’ and ‘control’ limits still matter, and reasonableness can still be argued on particular facts.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not convert ‘can be sufficient’ into ‘is always sufficient’ or ‘automatically establishes jurisdiction.’', 'Do not omit the ‘regular course of business’ limitation when discussing why one shipment may still support jurisdiction.', 'Do not omit the ‘control beyond stream of commerce’ requirement when addressing Amazon/FBA or other third-party fulfillment.', 'Do not generalize the rule to non-physical-goods cases (cookies, data interception, services) that the opinion says are handled under different internet-activity precedent.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query:
I’m drafting a 12(b)(2) motion in N.D. Cal. in a privacy/tort case against an out-of-state e-commerce platform. Can you give me a partner-ready analysis of whether we can win on specific personal jurisdiction in California and how to deal with the plaintiff’s reliance on the Ninth Circuit’s Shopify personal-jurisdiction decisions? Facts below.

Facts: Our client is a Canadian platform that provides embedded checkout/payment code to online merchants nationwide. Plaintiff is a California resident who bought from a California merchant while physically in California, and alleges our client installed tracking cookies and collected/sold personal data; the complaint alleges our client’s geolocation tech could tell the device was in California when the cookies were installed. Plaintiff is arguing California jurisdiction is proper under a “Calder effects” theory and cites the Ninth Circuit’s earlier Shopify panel decision and AMA Multimedia for the proposition that the platform must ‘differentially target’ California; we want to argue those cases show no jurisdiction absent forum-specific focus, and that Walden forbids relying on plaintiff’s location.
scenario_facts: ['Forum is the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; defendant is a Canadian corporation sued for privacy-related torts tied to cookies and data collection during checkout.', 'Complaint alleges defendant used geolocation technology to know the user’s device was located in California when it installed cookies and collected data; plaintiff was a California resident and was physically in California during the purchase.', 'Plaintiff argues specific personal jurisdiction based on intentional tort / “Calder effects” and emphasizes defendant’s knowledge of the user’s California location.', 'Defendant wants to argue no specific personal jurisdiction because the platform is nationwide and did not ‘differentially target’ California; defendant’s draft relies on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Shopify panel opinion and AMA Multimedia.', 'You should assume the opposition will argue the en banc Ninth Circuit decision in Briskin v. Shopify controls and that the earlier panel decision is no longer good law; they will also argue Walden does not bar jurisdiction where the defendant knowingly interacts with users in the forum via electronic means.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P033.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B01]'], ['DOC002[P017.B02]'], ['DOC001[P010.B04]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by asking whether each contested legal proposition is actually supported by the cited packet language, and whether the cited authority says what the memo claims it says. If the response states that a case was overruled, vacated, or remains good law, it must point to packet text showing that status; do not give credit for status assertions with no citation support. Do not give credit for invented holdings, invented procedural posture (e.g., claiming a case is Supreme Court or en banc when it is not), or invented “tests” that do not appear in the cited paragraphs. If the response relies on a rule (for example, that “differential targeting” is required or not required), it must cite the packet passages that adopt, reject, or overrule that rule. If the response uses Walden, it must tie its description to the packet’s actual statements about the plaintiff not being the only link and the need for defendant-forum contacts. Any claim about what the Ninth Circuit ‘currently requires’ must be supported by the en banc Briskin opinion, not by an unsupported generalization.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept paraphrases that materially change what a cited paragraph says about jurisdictional contacts.', 'Do not credit claims about a case’s precedential status (vacated/overruled) unless the response cites the packet’s explicit status language.', 'If the response imports external cases, statutes, or secondary sources not in the packet, treat those as unsupported even if they sound plausible.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for precedence if the response treats the vacated 2023 Shopify panel opinion as controlling Ninth Circuit law, or uses it as the governing rule without clearly acknowledging it was vacated and displaced by the en banc decision. Fail if the response relies on AMA Multimedia’s ‘forum-specific focus’ / ‘differential targeting’ requirement as a binding rule in the Ninth Circuit after Briskin, because the en banc Briskin decision expressly overruled that requirement and therefore it cannot be used as the governing standard. This is legally wrong because, in the Ninth Circuit, an en banc decision controls over prior panel decisions, and an opinion that has been vacated has no precedential force on the point for which it was vacated; similarly, an overruled rule cannot be applied as current law. To pass, the response must (i) identify Briskin (en banc) as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on the Shopify fact pattern, (ii) note that the panel decision was vacated, and (iii) explain that differential targeting is not required because Briskin overruled that line of cases. The response must still accurately incorporate Supreme Court constraints from Walden (defendant’s forum contacts; plaintiff not the only link) while explaining how Briskin reads Walden in the e-commerce context rather than ignoring Walden altogether.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding precedent in the Ninth Circuit; at most it may be background, and only if its vacatur is disclosed.', 'Do not apply AMA Multimedia’s ‘forum-specific focus’/‘differential targeting’ requirement as the governing test after Briskin expressly overruled it.', 'Do not cite persuasive out-of-circuit authority (e.g., Seventh Circuit internet-jurisdiction cases) as if it can override Supreme Court or Ninth Circuit en banc precedent in a California federal case.', 'Do not argue that plaintiff’s residence/location alone creates jurisdiction in a way that contradicts Walden’s defendant-forum-contact focus; reconcile any argument with Walden’s rule that the plaintiff cannot be the only link to the forum.']}

user_query:
Can you give me a partner-ready analysis of whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion (or at least a strong personal-jurisdiction argument) in the Northern District of California for our e-commerce platform client in a cookie/data-collection privacy suit? I’m specifically trying to understand whether we can still push the “no differential targeting / nationwide, forum-agnostic service” line we’ve used before, and whether the older Ninth Circuit cases help us at all.

Facts: Plaintiff is a California resident who used his phone in California to buy from a California merchant’s website that embedded our client’s checkout/payment tools. The complaint alleges our client’s scripts installed cookies on his device, collected geolocation/IP/device and payment-related information, compiled a consumer profile, and shared/sold that data to third parties. Client is incorporated and headquartered outside California, has no California offices or employees, and offers the same services nationwide. Plaintiff will argue we “knew” he was in California because of geolocation at the time the cookies were set.
scenario_facts: ['Forum is the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.', 'Claims sound in privacy/data-related tort theories tied to alleged cookie installation, geolocation/IP capture, and downstream profiling/sharing/sale of consumer data.', 'Plaintiff was physically in California when the alleged cookie installation and data capture occurred, and plaintiff pleads the platform used geolocation technology that identified his device as located in California at the relevant time.', 'Defendant platform is incorporated and headquartered outside California; it offers services to merchants nationwide and asserts it does not “differentiate” California from other states in how it operates.', 'The litigation team has located older Ninth Circuit authorities suggesting a plaintiff must show a defendant’s internet activity had a “forum-specific focus” (sometimes described as requiring “differential targeting”) to establish express aiming; the team wants to know whether that framing remains usable after later Ninth Circuit authority.', 'A correct memo must address the current controlling Ninth Circuit authority hierarchy (en banc vs. panel; overruled vs. still-good law) and should not treat vacated or overruled decisions as binding precedent in the Ninth Circuit.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P033.B02]', 'DOC002[P034.B04]'], ['DOC002[P017.B02]'], ['DOC002[P036.B01]', 'DOC002[P036.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by checking that every quoted rule or key proposition is actually supported by the cited passage and that the authority’s status is described accurately. If the response attributes a rule to a document that does not say it (for example, claiming a case “requires differential targeting” without support in the cited text), treat that as a citation integrity failure even if the case name is real. If the response cites materials not in the packet, that is not automatically disqualifying, but any legal rule that cannot be verified in the packet should be treated as unsupported and graded down. Pay special attention to whether the memo correctly reports procedural posture (e.g., vacatur) and overruling language, because misreporting that is both a factual and legal support problem. If a response paraphrases broadly, it still must be traceable to the cited blocks; vague citations that do not match the proposition should be treated as unreliable. If the response invents page/block cites, quotes, or holdings, it fails citation integrity.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit propositions that are not anchored to the cited block’s actual language and context.', 'Do not accept a citation to a case summary/headnote as if it were the holding unless the cited block contains that rule.', 'If the memo asserts a decision was vacated/overruled (or not), it must cite packet text showing that status.', 'Be alert to mixing up which court decided what; en banc majority vs. concurrences vs. dissents matter for what counts as the holding.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for precedence if the memo treats the 2023 three-judge panel decision as controlling Ninth Circuit law despite it being vacated, or if it treats AMA Multimedia’s “forum-specific focus/differential targeting” requirement as still binding after it was expressly overruled en banc. That mistake is legally wrong because an en banc Ninth Circuit decision binds later panels and district courts within the circuit, and a vacated panel opinion has no precedential force; relying on either as the operative rule misstates what governs the forum court. To pass, the memo must (1) identify that the panel decision was vacated and therefore cannot be cited as controlling authority, and (2) recognize that the en banc court overruled the differential-targeting line and explain the current rule accordingly. The memo must also reconcile any reliance on Walden by using the en banc court’s explanation of why Walden does not compel a different result in the e-commerce/cookie context, rather than using Walden to resurrect the overruled differential-targeting test. A passing answer can still mention the older cases for background, but it must clearly label them as noncontrolling (vacated/overruled) and must ground the recommendation in the controlling en banc holding.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding precedent or as the current Ninth Circuit test; it can be, at most, nonbinding background.', 'Do not argue that “differential targeting” is a required element for express aiming after the en banc decision expressly overruled that requirement.', 'Do not rely on overruled precedent (or overruled passages) as if they still govern, especially where the en banc opinion identifies the overruling by name.', 'Do not elevate a dissenting opinion’s view of Supreme Court precedent over the en banc majority holding in the same case.', 'When Supreme Court precedent is discussed, follow the en banc court’s application/interpretation for Ninth Circuit purposes unless it clearly conflicts with the Supreme Court’s actual holding as quoted in the packet.']}

user_query:
I need a partner-ready short memo on whether we have a viable Rule 12(b)(2) motion for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in the Northern District of California for an out-of-state e-commerce/payment platform defendant. Defense-side research flagged the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel decision as helpful; please assess whether we can rely on it and what the controlling law actually is.

Facts: Our client is a Canadian platform that provides embedded checkout/payment code to merchants nationwide. Plaintiff (a California resident) alleges that while shopping from a device in California, our client installed tracking cookies, captured geolocation/device data, compiled a consumer profile, and monetized/“shared” that data. Plaintiff pleads California privacy/tort claims and argues the platform deliberately targeted him in California because it knew his device was located there when it placed the cookies.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California; any appeal would go to the Ninth Circuit.', 'The defendant is not incorporated in California and does not claim to be ‘at home’ there; the dispute is about specific (case-linked) jurisdiction.', 'The complaint alleges the platform uses geolocation technology to know the user’s device is in California when cookies are installed and data is collected/sold.', 'A junior on the team circulated the Ninth Circuit’s November 2023 panel opinion in Briskin v. Shopify stating there was no specific jurisdiction for similar allegations, and suggested we quote its ‘no express aiming’ analysis as controlling.', 'We are drafting as of February 2026, after the Ninth Circuit issued an en banc decision in Briskin (filed April 21, 2025).', 'The memo should address authority hierarchy explicitly: what is binding in this posture (Supreme Court vs Ninth Circuit en banc vs panel decisions; what to do with vacated/overruled circuit precedent).']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P017.B02]', 'DOC002[P033.B02]', 'DOC002[P035.B01]'], ['DOC002[P036.B01]', 'DOC002[P036.B03]', 'DOC002[P037.B02]'], ['DOC001[P010.B04]', 'DOC001[P016.B03]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by checking whether each concrete legal proposition is actually supported by the cited packet text. The response should not attribute binding status, holdings, or quoted language to a source that does not say those things in the cited pages/blocks. If the answer claims that a case is “vacated,” “overruled,” or “controlling,” it must cite the portion of the packet that states that status, not general background knowledge. Do not give credit for legal tests, elements, or factual assertions that are not anchored in the cited blocks, even if they sound plausible. If the response discusses Ninth Circuit precedent being overruled, it must tie that statement to the en banc Briskin opinion’s explicit overruling language rather than implying it. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the direction and substance must match the cited text. Any mention of Supreme Court principles (e.g., plaintiff cannot be the only link) must be traceable to Walden’s language in the packet, not to outside cases or memory.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept uncited statements that the 2023 Briskin panel ‘still governs’ unless the packet supports it; the packet states it was vacated.', 'Do not accept claims about what ‘AMA’ or other cases held unless the response cites the en banc opinion’s description/overruling discussion in the packet.', 'If the response asserts the governing test or a key Walden principle, require a citation to the specific Walden passages provided, not generic due process talk.', 'If the answer quotes or closely paraphrases any rule (e.g., ‘plaintiff cannot be the only link’), it must cite the block where that phrasing appears.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for a precedence error if the response treats the November 2023 Briskin panel decision as binding or controlling authority in the Ninth Circuit after the April 2025 en banc Briskin opinion. The packet expressly reflects that the 2023 panel decision was vacated and that the en banc court reversed the district court and adopted a different specific-jurisdiction approach for Shopify-like facts, including rejecting a differential-targeting requirement and overruling contrary circuit precedent (including AMA’s differential-targeting rationale). That hierarchy matters because, within the Ninth Circuit, an en banc decision controls over a panel, and a vacated panel opinion has no precedential force; relying on it as governing law is legally wrong even if its reasoning seems helpful. A passing answer must (1) identify the en banc Briskin decision as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on these facts, (2) recognize and explain that the 2023 panel opinion is vacated and thus not controlling, and (3) correctly integrate Supreme Court Walden as the higher authority while describing how the en banc court distinguished/handled Walden in this e-commerce context. The answer may still discuss the vacated panel for historical context, but only if it clearly labels it as vacated/nonprecedential and does not use it to state the governing rule. Also fail if the response relies on the overruled ‘differential targeting/forum-specific focus’ requirement as a continuing prerequisite in the Ninth Circuit after en banc Briskin.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as precedential; it can’t supply the governing rule post-vacatur.', 'Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit standard (e.g., differential targeting/forum-specific focus) as if it remains required after en banc Briskin overruled it.', 'Do not let persuasive out-of-circuit authority or district court reasoning override controlling Supreme Court and Ninth Circuit en banc holdings.', 'Do not cite Walden for a proposition the en banc court specifically addressed without acknowledging the en banc court’s distinction and application in the packet.', 'Do not imply that older circuit language survives unchanged when the en banc opinion explicitly overrules it and sets a new rule.']}

Penal Code §§ 631(a) and 632) for (i) who counts as a “party” to the communication vs. a third-party “interceptor,” and (ii) what qualifies as “interception” in an online checkout/session-tracking context. Please quote the key language and give pincites to the leading California Supreme Court cases (e.g., Ribas v. Clark, Kearney v. Salomon Smith Barney, and Flanagan v. Flanagan), and summarize the elements we should attack.

Facts: Plaintiff alleges that when he checked out on a merchant’s website, our e-commerce platform embedded scripts/cookies that captured his keystrokes and payment details and routed them to our servers without notice or consent. He pleads CIPA 631(a)/632 and related privacy claims and wants statutory damages.
scenario_facts: ['You are assisting defense counsel for an out-of-state e-commerce/payment platform defendant sued in the Northern District of California.', 'The complaint alleges privacy-related torts and California statutory claims based on online checkout tracking, including claims labeled as California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) claims under Cal. Penal Code §§ 631(a) and 632.', 'The lawyer wants to support a Rule 12(b)(6) merits attack focused on whether the defendant is a third-party “interceptor” or a “party” to the communication and what conduct constitutes “interception.”', 'The lawyer specifically requests verbatim quotations with pinpoint citations to California Supreme Court authorities (Ribas v. Clark; Kearney v. Salomon Smith Barney; Flanagan v. Flanagan) and also requests the elements of the statutory claims.', 'The only provided research packet consists of the eight documents in this packet corpus, which primarily discuss personal jurisdiction (Walden and Ninth Circuit internet jurisdiction cases) and, in the Briskin materials, merely list the existence of CIPA claims without providing the statutory text or California Supreme Court merits holdings.']

user_query:
Can you draft a partner-ready memo section on Article III standing for a cookie/data-tracking privacy class action, with the governing rule from Spokeo v. Robins and TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez? Please include the key quote(s) on “concrete injury” and “risk of future harm,” plus pincites, and then summarize the leading Ninth Circuit application to web-tracking claims.

Facts: We represent a payment-platform provider sued in N.D. Cal. The complaint alleges the platform invisibly installs cookies on consumers’ devices during checkout, collects device identifiers and geolocation, and uses/sells that data without consent. Plaintiff pleads statutory privacy claims (CIPA/CCPA/UCL-type theories) and seeks classwide damages. We’re evaluating a Rule 12(b)(1) motion for lack of standing.
scenario_facts: ['You are assisting a litigation team preparing an internal memo for a partner evaluating an early Rule 12(b)(1) standing motion in a California privacy putative class action involving cookies/geolocation/data monetization.', 'The only materials you may rely on are the eight documents in the provided packet (DOC001–DOC008). No outside research is available for this request.', 'The partner specifically asked for Article III standing authority from Spokeo v. Robins and TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez, including direct quotations and pincites, as well as a Ninth Circuit web-tracking/cookie standing application.', 'The packet focuses on personal jurisdiction doctrine (including Walden v. Fiore and Ninth Circuit internet-contacts cases such as Briskin v. Shopify, Herbal Brands, Axiom Foods, AMA Multimedia, and Mavrix Photo) and includes some discussion of California privacy statutes in the pleadings background, but it may not contain Article III standing cases or tests.', 'A compliant response can (and should) flag that the requested standing authorities/quotes are not present in the packet and therefore cannot be quoted or cited from this record; it may briefly explain the packet’s limited scope and suggest what additional sources would be needed.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002[P014.B04]']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item is designed to catch fabricated or unsupported authority. The packet does not include Spokeo v. Robins, TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez, or any other Article III standing case law, so any response that supplies quotes, holdings, rule statements, or pincites for those cases should be graded as a failure for citation integrity. Likewise, the packet does not provide a Ninth Circuit “leading” standing decision for cookie/web-tracking claims; naming one with a citation, year, or quoted language as if it were sourced from the packet is also a failure. It is not enough for an answer to sound legally plausible—if it presents a case name, citation, or quotation that cannot be found in DOC001–DOC008, it fails. Minor paraphrase of what the packet actually says about jurisdiction is fine, but it must not be laundered into supposed standing doctrine. A fully compliant answer should explicitly say the packet lacks the requested standing authorities and decline to invent citations or quotes, while optionally pointing out that at least one packet opinion states it addresses personal jurisdiction only.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not quote or provide pincites for Spokeo or TransUnion; they are not in the packet.', 'Do not invent a Ninth Circuit standing case (name, citation, or holding) about cookies/session replay/web tracking.', 'Do not cite non-packet statutes or regulations (e.g., constitutional standing tests) with fake reporters or docket numbers.', 'Do not attribute Article III standing discussions to packet cases that only address personal jurisdiction or pleading notice.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}
